title: How to Invest $2 Million at Age 70 for Income and Stability
subtitle: A Complete Guide to Building a Comfortable Retirement Portfolio
content:
How to Invest $2 Million at Age 70 for Income and Stability

I'm Tyler, a former financial advisor and portfolio manager, and now I make financial content for free so you don't have to pay for it.

Investing Strategy

Here's exactly how I'd invest $2 million at age 70 if I wanted more income and less growth.

1. Invest in SCHD

I'd start by putting $1.2 million in SCHD. This is Schwab's US Dividend Equity ETF, which focuses on stable, dividend-centric companies. This provides lower expected growth but additional income, acting as my new paycheck at 70.

2. Invest in BND

Next, I would allocate $600,000 into BND, Vanguard's Total Bond Market ETF. This will give me stability when stocks drop, serving as my safety net during market downturns.

3. Invest in a Money Market Fund

The remaining $200,000 would go into a money market fund like Fidelity's SPAXX for liquidity and peace of mind. This is my "buy-the-dip" fund for being 70 years old, even if I still believe timing the market is a bad idea.

4. Annual Withdrawals

I would withdraw 6% annually from SCHD, roughly $72,000 per year. I'd make sure to sell monthly, as markets tend to be higher by year's end.

5. Total Annual Income

This would give me approximately $40,000 a year from the SCHD dividend yield, $18,000 a year from bond interest, another $8,000 a year from money market yield, plus $30,000 from Social Security, providing a total annual income of about $168,000.

Conclusion

This plan works for most of us who aren't looking for growth after 70. If any of this is helpful, sign up for my free weekly newsletter by clicking the link in my bio. Each week, I'll send you over another money playbook that actually works.
